A **trident** is a kind of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

Tridents have a special +4 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") bonus against [swimming monsters](/wiki/Swimmer "Swimmer") that are in [water](/wiki/Water "Water"), and a secondary +2 to-hit bonus against any ​S [snake](/wiki/Snake_\(monster_class\) "Snake (monster class)") or ​; [sea monster](/wiki/Sea_monster "Sea monster") that is not in water.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[Eating](/wiki/Eat "Eat") a trident while while [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a [metallivore](/wiki/Metallivore "Metallivore") produces [YAFM](/wiki/YAFM "YAFM") and exercises [wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Generation

Tridents are one of the rarer weapons in the game, making up only about 0.8% of all randomly generated weapons.

[Horned devils](/wiki/Horned_devil "Horned devil") have a 3⁄4 chance of [being generated with a trident](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory"), and [salamanders](/wiki/Salamander "Salamander") have a 2⁄21 chance (\~9.5%) of being generated with one.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

## Trident skill

| Trident |                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| ------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Max     | [Role](/wiki/Role "Role")                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| Basic   | - [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer"), [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist"), [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie"), [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") |
| Skilled | * [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman"), [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest")                                                                                                 |

Tridents are the only weapon to use the trident [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill"). There are no [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") tridents.

## Strategy

Though tridents are not typically sought out due to their relative rarity, they are a solid option for [twoweaponing](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon"). Tridents are the most damaging weapon against large monsters that can be used in the off-hand: they average one more point of damage versus large monsters compared to a [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword") or [katana](/wiki/Katana "Katana"), and are also comparable to [sabers](/wiki/Saber "Saber") and [crysknives](/wiki/Crysknives "Crysknives") in terms of output. However, players will usually obtain the aforementioned items and/or another viable off-hand weapon before encountering a trident.

## Average damage calculation

The average damage calculations in the following table do not include bonuses from [weapon skills](/wiki/Skill "Skill"), [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength"), or from using a [blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed") weapon against [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") or [demons](/wiki/M2_DEMON "M2 DEMON").

| Weapon     | Small monsters                                                                            | Large monsters                                                                           |

| +7 trident | ![\frac{1+6}{2}+1+7=\bold{11.5}](/images/math/d/5/e/d5e743696cf90f61d79b018db68487f9.png) | ![\frac{3+12}{2}+7=\bold{14.5}](/images/math/2/9/5/29599efabfb221553c09fbb4722710f0.png) |

## History

The trident first appears in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Trident](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trident "wikipedia:Trident")***

[![](/images/thumb/f/fc/Trident%2C_Burmese%2C_18th_century.JPG/300px-Trident%2C_Burmese%2C_18th_century.JPG)](/wiki/File:Trident,_Burmese,_18th_century.JPG)



A real world trident

Tridents have origins dating back to ancient Greece and Rome, and have been used for both fishing and combat historically and in modern times; in warfare, tridents were favored for their long reach and ability to disarm and dismount horse-riding combatants. A trident is the divine instrument of the Greek god [Poseidon](/wiki/Poseidon "Poseidon"), as indicated by the encyclopedia entry - this can explain the to-hit bonus against sea monsters and swimmers, as does its uses in fishing. The trident also sees use often in heraldry and military emblems.

The word "trident" originates from the Latin *tridentis* (lit. "three teeth"), referring to its trio of smooth tines: tridents designed primarily for fishing usually have barbed tines. This is part of the basis for the 3 dice used to calculate damage versus large monsters; the trident is also explicitly noted as a "spearish" weapon by the code, hence its position in the list of objects and its hitdie versus small monsters.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

In *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, [tridents](http://www.dandwiki.com/wiki/SRD:Trident) deal 1d8 base damage versus opponents, but have a lower critical hit multiplier than the [long spear](http://www.dandwiki.com/wiki/SRD:Spear), which has the same hitdie. This results in tridents having lower average damage, though tridents also allow the use of a shield or an off-hand weapon.

## Messages

- That was pure chewing satisfaction!

  You ate a trident while in the form of a metallivore.

- Four out of five dentists agree.

  As above, while [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating").

## Variants

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), [merfolk](/wiki/Merfolk_\(starting_race\) "Merfolk (starting race)") characters in any role that would start with a spear start with a [trident]() instead.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), Infidels can unlock and train the trident skill to Expert if they are [crowned](/wiki/Crowned "Crowned"). [tortle](/wiki/Tortle_\(starting_race\) "Tortle (starting race)") Barbarians start the game with a +0 trident in place of their two-handed weapon.

[Angelslayer](/wiki/Angelslayer "Angelslayer") is an [unaligned](/wiki/Unaligned "Unaligned") [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") trident.

A trident can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a [scimitar](/wiki/Scimitar "Scimitar") and a [spear](/wiki/Spear "Spear").

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), [Poseidon's Treasure](/index.php?title=Poseidon%27s_Treasure\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Poseidon's Treasure (page does not exist)") is an artifact trident that acts as the [Diver](/wiki/Diver "Diver")'s first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift").

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), in addition to EvilHack details, tortle [Undead Slayers](/wiki/Undead_Slayer "Undead Slayer") start with silver [tridents]() instead of silver spears.

## Encyclopedia entry

Poseido(o)n, lord of the seas and father of rivers and fountains, was the son of Chronos and Rhea, brother of Zeus, Hades, Hera, Hestia and Demeter. His rank of ruler of the waves he received by lot at the Council Meeting of the Gods, at which Zeus took the upper world for himself and gave dominion over the lower world to Hades.  
Poseidon is associated in many ways with horses and thus is the god of horses. He taught men how to ride and manage the animal he invented and is looked upon as the originator and guardian deity of horse races.  
His symbol is the familiar trident or three-pronged spear with which he can split rocks, cause or quell storms, and shake the earth, a power which makes him the god of earthquakes as well. Physically, he is shown as a strong and powerful ruler, every inch a king.

\[ The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends of All Nations,  
     by Herbert Robinson and Knox Wilson ]
